Models

We have developed two models of the guanidine-induced curing process. The basic assumption of both models is that the addition of GdnHCl to the culture medium prevents further propagation of [PSI+] within the cell. Therefore, on cell division, some of the existing [PSI+] propagons are passed to the daughter cell. As a result, the mean number of prion propagons per cell decreases over time and eventually cells without prions ([psi-] cells) appear. This is the mechanism first suggested by Eaglestone et al. (200?).

 

Our two models differ in the way in which the cell division process is modelled and in the separation of prion propagons between mother and daughter cells.

 

MODEL 1 assumes that cell division is an age-dependent branching process and that each propagon present in the mother cell has probability 1/2 of being passed to the daughter.

 

MODEL 2 assumes an asymmetric model of S. cerevisiaecell division, first proposed by Green (1981). Furthermore, each propagon present in the mother cell has probability p of being passed to the daughter, where both prior considerations and experimental data suggest that p<1/2.
